ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Prof. Wexler pushes students to examine a problem from all possible angles with empathy and compassion. Its a valuable skill set to have when working on issues of public space and interaction. I gained a level of nuance for the effects of modifying public sculpture on the public body that I did not have before.
I learned so much about Yale, cultural memory, American history and culture, and the sociopolitics of sculptures.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was excellent. I have no recommendations for improvement. It was exactly the content and problem solving that I hoped it would be.
The readings were not very evenly spaced--there were a ton at the beginning of the semester, and then none at the end. Ideally these would've been spread out more evenly.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely, this is the best course I have taken a Yale University thus far.
Highly! It's a really small seminar with an incredible teacher, and not a lot of work. Not to mention, you talk about really fascinating concepts--I definitely recommend!
